node.title: I just couldn't do it: Life is back to breakneck speed after lockdown and sometimes the juggle is too much
node.alt: A woman stands at a busy city intersection as cars pass by.
node.description: I had sorted a Tetris puzzle of interlocking pieces of friends and family to step in and help â€” but if one piece of the jigsaw fell out, the whole lot would fall over, writes Virginia Trioli.
node.content:
["In the end it turned out I couldn't.", "Couldn\u2019t do it all. Couldn't do the caring, the fetching and carrying, the cooking and the sorting. Couldn't do the day job with the extra work, the evening run with the early starts.", "Couldn't\u00a0read all the books, all the papers, listen to all the news as well as all the mum stuff.", "Couldn't\u00a0sit up half the night with a feverish child and bounce out of bed at 4am.", "Couldn't keep all those pretty coloured balls in the air all at the same time, spinning and whirling, an amazing sight to see.", "So when the news came through that after 10 days of managing this mad juggle my husband was going to be caught up in the snap 72-hour quarantine of returning overseas travellers, I knew the game was over.", "I had sorted a Tetris puzzle of interlocking pieces of friends and family to step in and do this bit, sleep over that night, do this school run right up until his return \u2014 but if one piece of the jigsaw fell out, the whole lot would fall over.", "I said quietly to myself, I can't do this.", "Something was going to have to give. I made the call and bowed out of something, something big.", "
The magical juggle is over
", "I texted a friend, tearful and disappointed in myself. She replied simply: sometimes you just have to let the balls fall.", "I could see that sad clown in the spotlight: the coloured balls fall to the floor, the magical juggle over. No applause. Lights out. Exit, stage right.", "How did we get back to this place?\u00a0\u00a0Friends tell me they are already overwhelmed by a rapid return to life as normal that now feels as strange as it was once familiar. The demands are returning, the pressure to say yes, the diary is filling, and all those go-slow lessons of the pandemic quickly forgotten.", "I remember how much of it was, and it was nuts. My handwritten diary \u2014 an overfilled thing of horror to some I work with \u2014 looks like the last 18 months never happened, and I must tell you, I vowed I would not go back to that place.", "Are you having those conversations now? The ones that start with \"how did we ever live that way?\" as you look back on a breakneck life and try to carve out another way of working and living?", "When retiring federal Health Minister Greg Hunt said that his children had told him he had one last chance left to be a proper father, I wonder how that landed with him. I already live with the anxiety that all my child will recall of his first years is his mother always hurrying him to the next thing, her eye on the clock as it relentlessly ticked down to an early bedtime.", "Another friend tells me of her sister, now a single mother, and the fragile balance of a life that works only if absolutely nothing goes wrong. And of course, something always goes wrong.", "
We haven't learnt
", "I suspect we are living in, yet again, a pivotal moment: one in which the memory of what we have learned and very much wanted to take from this pandemic experience is just fresh enough to remember but fading so fast in the delight of returning to normal that the most important elements could easily be lost.", "And on this damn pandemic, this weekend you can debate among yourselves Macquarie Dictionary\u2019s choice for word of the year: with so many now awfully familiar terms to choose from \u2013 was this the right one?", "Have a safe and happy weekend, and if you\u2019re a Beatles fan but understandably not so keen on signing up to all the streaming services \u2013 well, then you have a dilemma.", "This is the documentary that everyone is talking about \u2013 a labour of love by Peter Jackson that spans eight hours and attempts to rewrite the narrative of their bitter end.", "The irony is that they wear turmoil well, and this Beatle non-believer reckons the music proves it: no better albums than Let it Be and their final door-slam and walk-out, Abbey Road. So let me jump ahead, cut right to the bitter end and bring you the beauty that can come from chaos. If only all break-ups were this brilliant. \u00a0\u00a0", "Virginia Trioli is presenter on Mornings on\u00a0ABC Radio\u00a0Melbourne and the former co-host of\u00a0ABC\u00a0News Breakfast."]
